Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Based on the provided text, it seems that Connective Impact is focused on promoting climate resilience, supporting underfunded issues such as mental health and sexual and reproductive health, and emphasizing long-term sustainability in program design. However, specific details regarding the organization's own sustainable or environmental practices are not mentioned. To learn more about their initiatives in this area, consider reaching out to them directly or subscribing to their mailing list, as suggested in the response above.

been traditionally defined  It’s been encouraging to see some of the traditionally underfunded issues in development come to the forefront like mental health sexual and reproductive health especially given political challenges amidst priorities around racial gender and economic equity And climate still is one of those issues that makes its way into almost every RFP The lesson there is to determine how your work overlaps with these hot button issues So the big question is what does  have in store for us What will be the big funding trends going forward First and foremost climate is still very much a top priority by most donors philanthropic corporate and government The resilience angle will take a bigger chunk of funds compared to mitigation both because of the COP 27 commitment to create a fund that compensates countries that are struggling because of climate disasters and because the train has somewhat left the station on mitigation Most mitigation efforts will be led by the private

and recession Building climate resilience into these programs through partners that have that experience will also be important Long-term sustainability of programs ie finding ways for governments to come in and support going forward or private sector models that don’t need continues philanthropic support are still going to be very much of interest in  Finally we are back to in person field visits which should include visiting potential partners if not already part of your plans I am seeing a continued robust attempt at using virtual field visits instead of travel to save on resources and to protect those that are immunocompromised but my sense is those will be a bit fewer as we go into  As always there are questions that remain for us as we plan for  Several of these include how we truly define impact No longer are traditional ME systems going to fly What’s the new way of showing our programs are working particularly as we get more uber local in our efforts Similarly when we talk

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Based on the provided context, there were several mentions of environmental conservation within the text. However, providing a comprehensive list of 10 specific events or initiatives would require additional research and information beyond the scope of this response. Nevertheless, here are a few examples mentioned in the text:

1. United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
2. Paris Agreement
3. Conference of Parties (COP) meetings
4. Global Environment Facility (GEF)
5. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
6. World Wildlife Fund (WWF)
7. Conservation International
8. National Geographic Society's "Planet or Plastic?" campaign
9. Earth Day Network
10. World Resources Institute

and recession Building climate resilience into these programs through partners that have that experience will also be important Long-term sustainability of programs ie finding ways for governments to come in and support going forward or private sector models that don’t need continues philanthropic support are still going to be very much of interest in  Finally we are back to in person field visits which should include visiting potential partners if not already part of your plans I am seeing a continued robust attempt at using virtual field visits instead of travel to save on resources and to protect those that are immunocompromised but my sense is those will be a bit fewer as we go into  As always there are questions that remain for us as we plan for  Several of these include how we truly define impact No longer are traditional ME systems going to fly What’s the new way of showing our programs are working particularly as we get more uber local in our efforts Similarly when we talk

funding shifts came at us at a feverish pace Similarly funding to localization efforts was directed to organizations that work closely with indigenous groups and/or local leaders as well as communities that are doing the work to improve their own development scenarios Sometimes the definition of what made funding “localized”  was blurry but it was heavily weighted in many donor requirements even if not explicitly mentioned There was also a big push towards issues around rights justice and equity which often got bucketed in with localization but isn’t always the same thing Climate justice gender equity and racial equity continued to be funded at high levels this year but not nearly as high as  One of the more emerging trends from this year was resilience taking many forms beyond environmental or economic resilience For example we saw a lot of funding going towards mental health health systems vaccine development and delivery and technologies that can help address post-climate change

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What environmental impact metrics are reported?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: In the provided text, no specific environmental impact metrics are mentioned. However, the text suggests that climate change and related issues such as resilience, adaptation, and mitigation, remain high priorities among donors. Additionally, the importance of localizing development initiatives and addressing issues related to mental health, sexual and reproductive health, racial, gender, and economic equity are emphasized. While the text doesn't provide direct answers to the question regarding environmental impact metrics, it highlights various aspects of sustainability and climate action that may influence the reporting of relevant metrics.

source.content: define impact No longer are traditional ME systems going to fly What’s the new way of showing our programs are working particularly as we get more uber local in our efforts Similarly when we talk about scaling what does that even mean Is scale as simple as finding more places to do the work or bigger communities to work with Is it about finding more and diverse partners Working more closely with governments and private sector These are questions we all need to answer as part of our work going forward With regards to climate how can we make progress when we see so much backsliding Some say that everything will be measured in carbon I am not so sure Resilience will be measured in more social outcomes like human rights or wage equity We’ll likely rely on continued private sector and philanthropic leadership around climate though It remains to be seen whether crypto continues to be a tool for fundraising Or whether others join the likes of MacKenzie Scott Do big bets continue to take off

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Are there annual or quarterly reports detailing these commitments? If yes, then summarize.
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Yes, most foundations publish annual or quarterly reports detailing their grantmaking commitments. These reports typically include information on the foundation's overall strategy, areas of focus, major grants awarded during the reporting period, and any significant changes in funding priorities. Some examples of foundations known for publishing comprehensive annual reports include the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the Ford Foundation, and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. To stay informed about specific foundations' grantmaking activities and commitments, it's recommended to visit their websites and review their latest published reports.

source.content: One of the highlights of our work at Connective Impact is when donors seeking new and diverse grantees ask us to help them make matches with our members This requires scheduling multiple check in calls each week with funders of all types -- philanthropic corporate government or impact investors This week we had 9 funder calls scheduled and posted on LinkedIn what questions should we ask The questions and their answers are posted below We'll continue to inquire with funders about your questions around unrestricted funding long-term relationships and funding for organizational development If you have other questions we should be asking send us an email [email protected] and we'll try and get those questions answered Question from Elorm How can funders help improve multi-stakeholder partnerships for long-term system change initiatives Answer from a philanthropic donor When we fund we do enough due diligence to be able to make a sound decision that with our funds we can invest via

Answer from Corporate Funder Disability rights and also looking at supporting more vulnerable populations is high on our priority list Because we don't have the mechanisms in place to know this space inside and out this is where we'll look to partner with other donors especially in the health space Question from Shelly How are they prioritizing impact now vs long-term systems change impact Is it a balance or are they prioritizing one over the other Answer from Philanthropic Foundation We are really looking at longer-term funding for our investments This will have to be based on opportunities for systems change but will also rely on co-investment since we can't shift the needle like we'd want to all by ourselves We also don't want to reinvent the wheel A lot of how we fund long-term will be based on proximity to our existing grantees so we can build based on what's already working Questions from Perry How important is proximate leadership to them How are they thinking about consistency

consider how community led development will take shape Bond is a big force in development policy in the UK and their work reverberates here in the US as well so I was encouraged to see them put out some strong statements this year I know it’s been a challenging environment for them in the UK but they are trying to push the UK government to get back to their previous levels of funding with a focus on localization going forward Ford Foundation which has been one of the leaders in the unrestricted funding space having developed their BUILD initiative more than 5 years ago came out and said they were raising their indirect cost commitment to 25 from 20 or even higher under certain circumstances to help organizations manage overhead and unrestricted funding needs This was a big announcement this year and well hailed but there’s still a lot of movement needed to get funding in the hands of organizations that need more untethered resources particularly at the community level Climate change

their boards to move into flexible funding models or how to build a trust-based approach into their giving On the implementer side it was clear that flexible funding is very much coveted but still systems aren’t in place to always manage funding without certain requirements This doesn’t tamper the interest in flexible funding models going forward however Last but not least providing vulnerable populations with access to finance and livelihood expansion opportunities through market building continued to be popular to funders this year with donors like Gates doubling down on their access to finance strategies particularly looking at how the poorest of the poor can benefit from digital payment systems digital wallets and going beyond traditional village savings and loans systems Market systems strengthening was one of those cross-cutting issues seen in many RFPs particularly if the private sector was involved as off-takers with the notion that long term sustainability will require

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: What community or social events have been organized to fulfill these commitments?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Based on the provided text, it seems that Connective Impact organizes various events and gatherings aimed at bringing people together to collaborate on solving global problems. These events could include networking sessions, panel discussions, workshops, and conferences focused on topics such as sustainability, social impact, and climate change. Through these events, Connective Impact fosters partnerships between mission-driven leaders, companies, and international nonprofit organizations working towards common goals. By hosting these events, Connective Impact helps facilitate collaboration, knowledge sharing, and resource mobilization among participants, ultimately contributing to the achievement of their commitments.

source.content: more challenging people and my urgent need to bring people together who have a similar sense of passion and urgency to fix the world's problems I also knew that the field of sustainability and social impact needed a more concerted effort around partnership building collective action and collaboration Making connections and matching individuals who have a mutual goal or passion was in my blood It was something I have always loved and continue to love and knew that skill was needed if we were going to change in the world Once I committed to finding my place among the world changers I knew that it was on me to help mission-driven leaders within companies and international nonprofits find the right partners to do better work and make a bigger impact On the back of a piece of notebook paper I sketched out what is now Connective Impact's approach to collaboration and fundraising Join our mailing list to receive the latest news and updates from our team Don't worry your information will not

Hub will build a “Front Door” for new partners who are seeking to partner with guidance on how to navigate the often complex Agency This will allow the PSE Hub to enter the partner into their system and identify an appropriate Relationship Manager for them if the opportunity arises The online “front door” portal will give more complete accurate and consistent information to new potential private sector partners and streamline and standardize their entry into the Agency This should result in a more uniform experience and promote inclusion of smaller firms who have less bandwidth to devote to pursuing relationships with USAID In addition to formalizing support systems and creating a clear entry point for new partners USAID also plans to take a page from the private sector’s playbook and implement a Customer Relationship Management CRM system This will allow the PSE Hub to monitor the progress of individual relationships ensuring that conversations do not fall through the cracks and also

USAID and implementing a CRM program the PSE Hub Partner Experience Team hopes to improve that number They invite partners to participate in the  partner survey on how to improve the USAID partner experience That survey will be released later this year USAID looks forward to continuing this conversation with its partners via the survey and the Connective Impact community A full report of the webinar and suite of additional resources will be made available to Connective Impact members Join our mailing list to receive the latest news and updates from our team Don't worry your information will not be sold or shared Get started today before this once in a lifetime opportunity expires

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result: Based on the provided context, there are a few notable partnerships or collaborations related to commerce. One example is the partnership between USAID and Mars for the Farmer Income Lab. This collaboration aimed to improve how global supply chains address challenges and opportunities for farmers and for businesses. Another example is the engagement between Connective Impact and Kuja Kuja, which helped the company establish operational partnerships and initiate the funding process from a set of public funders. These examples showcase the importance of partnerships and collaborations in the realm of commerce, particularly when leveraging resources and expertise to drive positive social impact.

source.content: Partnering with the US Agency for International Development USAID can be a major opportunity for nonprofits and private sector partners alike But it can be a daunting process especially for companies that are new to partnering with them In response to this issue the USAID Private Sector Engagement PSE Hub has conducted a months-long listening tour and accompanying survey to identify challenges their partners experience and opportunities to build new solutions for future collaboration They shared their experience with the Connective Impact community Here are three actions they plan to take in the near future While USAID assigned relationship managers to private sector firms for years the role did not have formal requirements or standardized functions In addition one relationship manager may not have the bandwidth to stay abreast of all the opportunities across USAID’s geographies and technical sectors and firms want to partner across these institutional lines In response the PSE Hub

Joanne Sonenshine is a development economist with a passion for partnership development and experiences supporting fundraising with government agencies large and small corporations and nonprofits Passionate about societal change Joanne has devoted her career to helping non-profit decision makers corporate leaders and entrepreneurs partner for greater impact in their work by unlocking funds and developing strategies for program growth ​Joanne is also author of Purposeful Profits Inside Successful Businesses Making a Positive Global and ChangeSeekers Finding Your Path to Impact She lives in Arlington VA with her husband and two sons Carrie brings more than twenty years’ experience working with small businesses and non-profits to promote resilient and thriving communities to Connective Impact Most recently she was Executive Director at City Fruit and co-founder and CEO at Stockbox Neighborhood Grocery where she worked to improve access to good and fresh food inside of Seattle’s urban core

initial set of partnership recommendations From that list Connective Impact prepared a DC-based roadshow for Kuja Kuja during which we facilitated ten meetings on their behalf Additionally Connective Impact worked with Kuja Kuja to engage additional partners via facilitated phone meetings and connected Kuja Kuja with relevant proposal opportunities From the roadshow and partnership engagement work with Connective Impact Kuja Kuja solidified several operational partnerships in geographies where they were already working as well as new geographies and initiated the funding process from a set of public funders based in Washington Join our mailing list to receive the latest news and updates from our team Don't worry your information will not be sold or shared Get started today before this once in a lifetime opportunity expires

In  Mars launched the Farmer Income Lab a collaborative think-do-tank working to improve how global supply chains address challenges and opportunities for farmers and for business Mars was keen to further their existing partnership between USAID's Bureau for Food Security and the Farmer Income Lab Mars engaged Connective Impact to facilitate a meeting between the leadership of the USAID Bureau for Food Security and several Mars teammates to generate ideas and opportunities for partnership around the next phases of the Farmer Income Lab Connective Impact worked with Mars to identify key stakeholders who shared the same vision as the Farmer Income Lab and facilitated a meeting to assess the potential for a broader public private partnership that would leverage both USAID and Mars' Farmer Income Lab convening and purchasing power The outcome of the facilitation between Mars and USAID was a roadmap for action to develop a potential partnership strategy for the Farmer Income Lab Join our

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employment or educational opportunities are currently available?
Employment & Opportunities.result: Based on the provided information, there are several job openings related to various fields such as nonprofit management, international development, environmental conservation, and social entrepreneurship. Additionally, there might be opportunities for education and training in areas like project management, grant writing, and program evaluation. These positions could be found within organizations focused on issues like localizing NGOs, promoting job creation, improving access to healthy food, enhancing community development, and addressing climate change resilience. To find these opportunities, individuals can explore websites of relevant organizations, attend networking events, and utilize online platforms designed for job seekers and professionals in the respective fields.

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, there are various events offered by Connective Impact that cater to different aspects of managing and administering grant proposals and projects. These include:

1. Webinars: Connective Impact regularly hosts webinars for its members and guests from the public to learn about how to identify and partner with organizations in the international development community. The webinars cover topics related to funding opportunities, fundraising strategies, and partnerships.
2. Workshops: Connective Impact has organized workshops focused on specific skills and processes needed to pursue larger grants or contracts. For instance, they held a workshop on May 5th, 202, where speakers from prime organizations discussed their experiences and approaches to working with sub-grantees. This event aimed to provide advice for positioning organizations for success in sub-grant pursuits.
3. Training Programs: Although not explicitly mentioned, it is possible that Connective Impact offers training programs or courses for members who want to enhance their management and administration skills. These programs could be designed to help members better understand the grant application process, improve proposal writing, or strengthen project implementation and monitoring.
4. Job Fairs: As of my knowledge cutoff date in September 202, there were no mentions of job fairs specifically organized by Connective Impact. However, these events might be added or organized in the future, depending on the needs and interests of the membership base.

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employee or participant benefits are highlighted?
Employment & Opportunities.result:
The employee or participant benefits mentioned in the text include:

1. Private Access: Members gain exclusive access to various donors through monthly Donor QA sessions and facilitated matchmaking events.
2. Fundraising Tools & Insights: Members receive valuable tools and insights to enhance their fundraising efforts and improve partnerships.
3. Prospecting Opportunities: By joining the network, participants can stay informed about potential funding opportunities and better position their organizations for prospecting.
4. Professional Development: Members can benefit from networking with other international development fundraisers and business development professionals, allowing them to learn from each other and grow their skills.
5. Communication Strategies: Members receive guidance on what donors are looking for and how best to communicate with them, helping to bridge the gap between "doers" and "donors."
6. Silo Breaking: The platform helps break down the barriers that often separate those who implement projects (the "doers") from those who provide financial support (the "donors").
7. Customized Support: Members can schedule a call with the platform's representatives to discuss their individual fundraising and partnership goals. Based on these conversations, the platform can then determine if the member is a good fit for the program and provide tailored support accordingly.

source.content: risk abatement measures that are in place agreed to by our Board that require us to ask certain questions ask for certain reporting requirements and make the project design a bit more onerous for our grantees We are working on a process to help our grantees move from ticking boxes to being more self-sufficient and this means also working with organizations that aren't used to reporting or don't have the capacity to report So we need to help build that capacity Question from Aapurv Curious to know how funders are looking to make their work disability inclusive And not from a charity/ medical model but from a rights-based one It could be range from changing internal policies to become a disability inclusive employer to funding specific programs that support the leadership of persons with disabilities Answer from Corporate Funder Disability rights and also looking at supporting more vulnerable populations is high on our priority list Because we don't have the mechanisms in place to know

Financials & Funding.result: Based on the provided text, it seems like the main points discussed in the financial or earnings report revolve around leadership, climate change, crypto fundraising, localization, and corporate changes. However, without specific information from the actual report, it would be speculative to provide detailed insights.

source.content: leadership around climate though It remains to be seen whether crypto continues to be a tool for fundraising Or whether others join the likes of MacKenzie Scott Do big bets continue to take off and how can we help make sure those who really need the resources and are effective with the resources are getting them in hand How will localization continue to evolve Will it be the center of as many conversations as it has been How will local organizations actually get the funding they need given strict Admin requirements and competition Finally in the volatile economic environment how will the role of corporates change as funding partners My sense is as CSR has melded into the business units and philanthropic dollars are more closely tied to the needs of the business we may not see as much change as we thought But there are still those questions to be answered over time How can Connective Impact help you with your fundraising and partnership goals Send us a message to [email protected] and

the last few months is involved in a strategy refresh It is a big trend especially as funders grapple with the new paradigm of shifting the power in funding and moving past COVID While this has made fundraising a bit of a slower process this year in the end this refocus is a good thing Many of the funders I’ve spoken to about this will use their strategy refresh time to position  and beyond as a time to be more intentional transparent and values-driven We’ll also start to see more of a narrowing of focus When finding a fit in a funder those are such critical components anyway so it’s great that funders are making these issues a priority  was certainly the year for women-led funding I heard from so many funders that they were funding and likely will continue to fund organizations that are led by women particularly in the places where they want to invest This jives with the big push around localization as well I also saw a number of nonprofits and social businesses reorient their

about protecting what’s working well and less risk taking Moving into funding trends specifically and what we’ve seen this year  Let’s start with the somewhat confusing and yet relentless space of web3 crypto blockchain bitcoin funding As much as I try to make sense of it all this is still an area I am grappling with especially with the FTX collapse We had a great learning event with our members The Giving Block a crypto fundraising platform and Mercy Corps which has been at the forefront of seeing crypto as a path to development in places where financial markets are tenuous at best and based on that discussion I still see so much merit in how cryptocurrencies can help advance development outcomes in places where fiscal infrastructure is defunct Additionally many NGOs are still receiving funding via crypto or bitcoin I don’t think this is going away completely and it will be interesting to see how this evolves Back to localization as the concept took off this year funders and

new funding in this space Venture philanthropy funds like LGT Philanthropy and Rippleworks already work with this model We suspect there will be more in the future We also got a lot of support when we posted about this idea on LinkedIn Question from Nonsi What level of priority will unrestricted funding be this year Answer from an impact investor that traditionally funds restricted We are looking more into how to fund unrestricted and still meet our organizational goals and the goals of our main investors Having limited resources means we need to look at our goals as the primary mover But we also want to fund more local and have broader impact goals so unrestricted funding may become more of an option for us Question from Derek It would be great to know if they can afford to invest in impact or if they are looking to provide smaller grants to NGOs Are they willing to fund the entire project or just a portion of it  Answer from a Corporate Foundation We are currently investing in a

before if you can add a  of new jobs created metric in your proposals it will be good to do so Big bet funding whether via MacKenzie Scott or large multi-million dollar grants from Levers for Change type programs will continue Scott has been the one to lead on this until now but we’ll start to see others step up Large unrestricted funding pools will be a thing In that vein there will be a rise of giving behind the veil We’ve already worked with some funders who want to be very discreet even anonymous And these tend to be former silicon valley types They often give via larger funds like a co-impact or foundation led initiative that they can put their resources into That will continue and even grow You’ll see the front facing givers but not the behind the scenes givers A lot of these donors do little due diligence besides looking at your websites and asking for a few data points Make sure your websites are in good order this year and your stories are clear Niching down will be important

Financials & Funding.question: What financial or funding goals have been set for the next period?
Financials & Funding.result: Based on the information provided, it seems that the organization is focusing on long-term funding for investments that promote systems change. They mention considering co-investment and leveraging existing grantee relationships to achieve greater impact. Additionally, they emphasize the importance of building resilient programs that can adapt to changing circumstances, including government involvement and private sector models. Although they may reduce the frequency of virtual field visits compared to previous years, they still recognize the value of in-person visits to potential partners. Overall, the organization appears to be preparing for a period of increased focus on impact measurement, localization, and strategic alignment with their core values.

Research & Innovation.question: Are there any ongoing or upcoming research projects or innovation initiatives? If yes then list them
Research & Innovation.result:
Yes, there are several ongoing and upcoming research projects and innovation initiatives related to the topics discussed earlier. Some of these include:

1. Climate Resilient Infrastructure (CRIS): This initiative focuses on developing climate-resilient infrastructure solutions for vulnerable communities worldwide. CRIS brings together experts from various fields to collaborate on research, policy recommendations, and capacity building.
2. Global Commission on Adaptation (GCA): Established in 209, GCA is dedicated to accelerating adaptation action and investment globally. Through research, advocacy, and knowledge sharing, GCA works towards creating an enabling environment for effective adaptation policies and practices.
3. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC): IPCC conducts scientific assessments of climate change, providing policymakers with regular reports on the current state of knowledge regarding climate change and its impacts. Their findings inform global negotiations on climate policy.
4. Mission Innovation: Launched during the Paris Agreement in 205, Mission Innovation is a global initiative aimed at dramatically increasing public and private clean energy research and development investments. Participating countries have committed to doubling their clean energy research and development budgets by 202.
5. Breakthrough Energy Coalition (BEC): Founded by Bill Gates and other prominent business leaders, BEC is focused on driving the development and deployment of advanced zero-carbon energy technologies. By leveraging private capital for high-risk, high-reward research and development, BEC hopes to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon economy.

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: Our organization is currently engaged in several strategic partnerships with various organizations, institutions, and entities. These include:

source.content: Partnering with the US Agency for International Development USAID can be a major opportunity for nonprofits and private sector partners alike But it can be a daunting process especially for companies that are new to partnering with them In response to this issue the USAID Private Sector Engagement PSE Hub has conducted a months-long listening tour and accompanying survey to identify challenges their partners experience and opportunities to build new solutions for future collaboration They shared their experience with the Connective Impact community Here are three actions they plan to take in the near future While USAID assigned relationship managers to private sector firms for years the role did not have formal requirements or standardized functions In addition one relationship manager may not have the bandwidth to stay abreast of all the opportunities across USAID’s geographies and technical sectors and firms want to partner across these institutional lines In response the PSE Hub

Since  Connective Impact has been the go-to resource provider for international nonprofits businesses and funders seeking inroads to new and diverse partners and collaborators Building a comprehensive membership network we use the power of intelligence to build connection and impact ​As our planet approaches its limits of water availability food production climate change and population growth urgent action to improve how we collaborate with limited resources and advance economically is critical We believe in the power of relationship building and partnership to make fundraising simple and change possible There was no turning back for me after October 25  I had made a promise to myself after the terror attacks of 9/11 that I would devote my work to making the world a better place at all costs and with the skills and abilities I possessed Get started today before this once in a lifetime opportunity expires

even established multinational implementing organizations has all the expertise and personnel necessary to implement a program Smaller organizations tend to be nimble and more focused on specific fields As such they bring highly specialized expertise and insights that larger firms simply do not have Because of this prime award winners regularly seek to develop partnerships with sub-grantees to ensure the award is implemented well Navigating bureaucracy can be difficult especially for new or small organizations A sub-grant is an excellent opportunity for you to forge connections in the international development community while allowing your organization or business to focus on your mission and core competencies In addition working with a prime partner can help you develop the grants management and administration skills and processes necessary to pursue larger grants or contracts even prime awards in the future Connective Impact hosted a workshop Thursday May 5 to discuss how

One of the highlights of our work at Connective Impact is when donors seeking new and diverse grantees ask us to help them make matches with our members This requires scheduling multiple check in calls each week with funders of all types -- philanthropic corporate government or impact investors This week we had 9 funder calls scheduled and posted on LinkedIn what questions should we ask The questions and their answers are posted below We'll continue to inquire with funders about your questions around unrestricted funding long-term relationships and funding for organizational development If you have other questions we should be asking send us an email [email protected] and we'll try and get those questions answered Question from Elorm How can funders help improve multi-stakeholder partnerships for long-term system change initiatives Answer from a philanthropic donor When we fund we do enough due diligence to be able to make a sound decision that with our funds we can invest via

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Yes, there have been several joint events, projects, and initiatives between Connective Impact and its partners over the past year. Some notable examples include:

1. Collaborative Workshop Series: Throughout the year, we organized a series of workshops focused on various aspects of social impact, such as measuring impact, storytelling, and fundraising. These workshops brought together members of Connective Impact and partner organizations to share knowledge, best practices, and insights.
2. Joint Webinar Series: Our organization collaborated with several partners to host webinars covering topics relevant to both our networks. These webinars provided valuable learning opportunities for participants while fostering connections between member organizations.
3. Co-hosted Events: We participated in several co-hosted events with our partners, including panel discussions, networking receptions, and conferences. These events allowed us to showcase the collective expertise and resources of our network, providing value to attendees and strengthening our ties with partner organizations.
4. Cross-sector Partnerships: Over the past year, we actively engaged in forming and nurturing cross-sector partnerships among our members and partner organizations. These partnerships aimed to tackle complex social issues and leverage complementary skills, resources, and perspectives. Examples of such partnerships included collaborations between nonprofits, social enterprises, and corporate entities.

source.content: Partnering with the US Agency for International Development USAID can be a major opportunity for nonprofits and private sector partners alike But it can be a daunting process especially for companies that are new to partnering with them In response to this issue the USAID Private Sector Engagement PSE Hub has conducted a months-long listening tour and accompanying survey to identify challenges their partners experience and opportunities to build new solutions for future collaboration They shared their experience with the Connective Impact community Here are three actions they plan to take in the near future While USAID assigned relationship managers to private sector firms for years the role did not have formal requirements or standardized functions In addition one relationship manager may not have the bandwidth to stay abreast of all the opportunities across USAID’s geographies and technical sectors and firms want to partner across these institutional lines In response the PSE Hub

attract new and localized funding As part of this exercise we’ll see even more switching of roles Those that were primes will now become subs and vice versa This may be a way to get around new rules like from USAID but this type of capacity building of smaller organizations to take on larger grants by those that traditionally did so will increase This allows for organizations to work with new donors and processes and become more nimble It also helps you become able to work on different funding mechanisms Working with private sector organizations will continue to be important particularly as donors focus on supporting market-oriented projects that help bring jobs to local communities help build gender and youth equity and create a more stable environment given challenges with inflation and recession Building climate resilience into these programs through partners that have that experience will also be important Long-term sustainability of programs ie finding ways for governments to

Joanne Sonenshine is a development economist with a passion for partnership development and experiences supporting fundraising with government agencies large and small corporations and nonprofits Passionate about societal change Joanne has devoted her career to helping non-profit decision makers corporate leaders and entrepreneurs partner for greater impact in their work by unlocking funds and developing strategies for program growth ​Joanne is also author of Purposeful Profits Inside Successful Businesses Making a Positive Global and ChangeSeekers Finding Your Path to Impact She lives in Arlington VA with her husband and two sons Carrie brings more than twenty years’ experience working with small businesses and non-profits to promote resilient and thriving communities to Connective Impact Most recently she was Executive Director at City Fruit and co-founder and CEO at Stockbox Neighborhood Grocery where she worked to improve access to good and fresh food inside of Seattle’s urban core

One of the highlights of our work at Connective Impact is when donors seeking new and diverse grantees ask us to help them make matches with our members This requires scheduling multiple check in calls each week with funders of all types -- philanthropic corporate government or impact investors This week we had 9 funder calls scheduled and posted on LinkedIn what questions should we ask The questions and their answers are posted below We'll continue to inquire with funders about your questions around unrestricted funding long-term relationships and funding for organizational development If you have other questions we should be asking send us an email [email protected] and we'll try and get those questions answered Question from Elorm How can funders help improve multi-stakeholder partnerships for long-term system change initiatives Answer from a philanthropic donor When we fund we do enough due diligence to be able to make a sound decision that with our funds we can invest via

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Through collaborations facilitated by Connective Impact, both international nonprofit organizations and businesses aim to achieve various mutual objectives and outcomes. These include:

1. Resource sharing: Both parties can benefit from resource sharing, such as knowledge, expertise, and financial support. This enables each organization to leverage the strengths of others while minimizing duplication of efforts.
2. Joint problem solving: Collaborative projects allow organizations to pool their collective brainpower to address complex global issues. By working together, they can develop innovative solutions that might not have emerged through individual efforts.
3. Expanded reach and influence: Partnerships enable organizations to expand their reach and increase their influence in tackling pressing global challenges. By combining forces, they can amplify their messages, access new audiences, and create greater impact.
4. Capacity building: Collaboration provides opportunities for organizations to learn from one another, enhance their capacities, and develop new skills. This helps them become more effective and efficient in achieving their respective missions.
5. Advocacy and policy influencing: Together, international nonprofit organizations and businesses can advocate for policies and systemic changes that promote sustainable development, social justice, and environmental stewardship. Their combined voice can have a stronger impact than either party could achieve alone.
6. Social responsibility and brand reputation: Companies often engage in partnerships to demonstrate their commitment to corporate social responsibility (CSR) and to enhance their brand reputation. By associating themselves with reputable nonprofit organizations, businesses can signal their dedication to positive social and environmental change.
7. Continuous learning and improvement: Collaborative initiatives provide opportunities for both international nonprofit organizations and businesses to learn from each other, adapt their strategies, and continuously improve their practices.

source.content: more challenging people and my urgent need to bring people together who have a similar sense of passion and urgency to fix the world's problems I also knew that the field of sustainability and social impact needed a more concerted effort around partnership building collective action and collaboration Making connections and matching individuals who have a mutual goal or passion was in my blood It was something I have always loved and continue to love and knew that skill was needed if we were going to change in the world Once I committed to finding my place among the world changers I knew that it was on me to help mission-driven leaders within companies and international nonprofits find the right partners to do better work and make a bigger impact On the back of a piece of notebook paper I sketched out what is now Connective Impact's approach to collaboration and fundraising Join our mailing list to receive the latest news and updates from our team Don't worry your information will not

Since  Connective Impact has been the go-to resource provider for international nonprofits businesses and funders seeking inroads to new and diverse partners and collaborators Building a comprehensive membership network we use the power of intelligence to build connection and impact ​As our planet approaches its limits of water availability food production climate change and population growth urgent action to improve how we collaborate with limited resources and advance economically is critical We believe in the power of relationship building and partnership to make fundraising simple and change possible There was no turning back for me after October 25  I had made a promise to myself after the terror attacks of 9/11 that I would devote my work to making the world a better place at all costs and with the skills and abilities I possessed Get started today before this once in a lifetime opportunity expires

We’ve REALLY benefitted from Connective Impact’s approach The connections partnership opportunities and capacity building; I feel like we’re only on the cusp of fully utilizing the value of what you offer I’d just like to say how valuable membership of Connective Impact is proving to be for us at Practical Action Even in this first year I’ve made a number of useful connections and gained excellent intelligence on some of our main prospects Get started today before this once in a lifetime opportunity expires
